Mei and MK stood in front of Bai Long Ma, both already in their prison worker disguises. They had been practicing their roles for hours, trying to perfect their acting so they wouldn't stand out.

"We need to know where Ao Lie is," Mei said, crossing her arms. "Do you have any ideas?"

Bai Long Ma hesitated before speaking. "There is a way," he said, looking down at his feet. "But it's not something we usually do."

"What is it?" MK asked.

Bai Long Ma sighed. "We have contacts inside the government. People who have been bribed or have their own reasons for wanting to help us. They have access to information that could tell us where Ao Lie is being held."

"So why don't we just use this method?" Mei asked.

Bai Long Ma looked at her seriously. "It's dangerous," he said. "If we get caught, those contacts will be exposed and they'll be punished. And if we keep using them, eventually the government will catch on and we'll lose our advantage."

Mei and MK exchanged a worried look. "But if we don't use it, we might never find Ao Lie," MK said.

Bai Long Ma nodded. "I know. But you have to understand, we can't just go around using this method whenever we want. We have to be careful."

Mei nodded thoughtfully. "So how do we do it?"

Bai Long Ma looked at her. "I'll make the arrangements. I'll tell you where to meet the contact and what to say. But you have to promise me, you'll be careful. And if anything goes wrong, you cut and run."

Mei and MK nodded in agreement. They knew they couldn't afford to take any risks.

Mei and MK are annoyed to discover that Bai Long Ma's group of rebels aren't as equipped to save Ao Lie as the "real" rebellion. Bai explains that most of them in his group are ex-university students who got in trouble with Spider Queen's minions, and the rebellion took them in to keep them safe - they're still rebels, they just don't have as ready access to the same resources as the "real" rebellion. Mei and MK exchanged a look of disappointment as they heard Bai's explanation. Mei spoke up first, "So, what do you suggest we do then?"

Bai sighed, "I wish there was more we could do. We're mostly a group of university students who got in trouble for speaking out against the Queen's regime. The rebellion took us in to keep us safe, but we're not as well-equipped as the main group."

MK chimed in, "But we have to do something. Ao Lie is one of us and we can't just leave him there."

Bai nodded, "I understand how you feel. We can try to gather some more information, but we have to be careful. We don't want to draw too much attention to ourselves."

Mei spoke up again, "Is there anything you can tell us about the prison system? Anything that might help us find Ao Lie?"

Bai thought for a moment before responding, "I don't know much about the prisons themselves, but I do know that there's one main prison in each major city. It's possible that's where he's being held."

MK nodded, "That's a start. We'll have to gather more information before we can make any moves."

Mei added, "And we'll have to be careful not to get caught. We don't want to end up in there with Ao Lie."

Bai nodded in agreement, "Yes, that would be counterproductive. I'll do what I can to help you from here, but you'll have to be the ones to take the risk."

Mei and MK exchanged another look, both determined to save their friend.

Bai Long Ma goes into another room. From behind the closed door, MK hears Bai talking with someone on what seems to be a video call. Bai insists they need to take advantage of the rebellion's resources to help these two students find their friend, and admits with some embarrassment that he sabotaged a station and this friend got arrested because he looked like Bai. Whoever Bai is talking to is annoyed to hear Bai sabotaged something without clearing it with rebel leadership first. Let's write that scene with details and dialogue.

MK leans in to listen as Bai Long Ma walks into another room to make a call. He can hear Bai's muffled voice, but not the other side of the conversation.

"Yes, I know," Bai is saying. "But these two students, they're our friends. We have to help them find their friend. And besides, we don't even know where he is yet."

MK strains to hear the other person's response, but only catches snippets of their conversation.

"I don't care if it was a small station," Bai continues. "It still caused damage to their system. And our friend got arrested because he looks like me."

There's a pause before the other person responds, and MK can almost hear their irritation through the closed door.

"You should have cleared it with the leadership before you did something like that," the voice says. "This is exactly why we have protocols in place."

Bai responds with a sheepish tone. "I know, I know. I just...I got carried away. And now we have to deal with the consequences."

MK hears the sound of the call ending and quickly straightens up as Bai walks back into the room.

"Everything okay?" MK asks, trying to sound nonchalant.

Bai gives him a small smile. "Just talking with the higher-ups. They're not thrilled that I sabotaged a station without clearing it with them first."

MK raises an eyebrow. "You did what now?"

Bai looks slightly sheepish. "I cut the power to one of the soldiers' stations in another city. It was only supposed to be temporary, but it ended up causing a lot more damage than I anticipated. And then, unfortunately, your friend got caught up in it because he looks like me."

MK can't help but shake his head. "You really didn't think this through, did you?"

Bai lets out a rueful laugh. "No, I guess I didn't. But I'll deal with the consequences. Right now, let's focus on finding your friend."

Bai Long Ma steps into a nearby room and closes the door. MK can hear Bai's muffled voice from the other side.

"I know we're not supposed to overstep our boundaries, but these two students need our help," Bai says, sounding urgent.

MK strains to listen, but can't quite make out the other person's voice.

"I understand that, Bai," the voice replies, "but sabotaging a station without clearing it with leadership first is not the way to go about it. We can't risk exposing ourselves for individual cases."

"I know, I know," Bai says, his voice low. "I messed up, and I'm sorry for that. But please, this friend of theirs is in trouble because he looks like me. We need to do something to help them."

MK can sense Bai's desperation through the door. He looks over at Mei, who is frowning in concern.

There's a pause on the other end of the line before the voice finally responds. "Alright, I'll see what I can do. But this is a one-time exception, Bai. Don't let it happen again."

"Thank you, thank you," Bai says, relief evident in his voice.

Mei and MK watch as Bai Long Ma disappears into another room, closing the door behind him. They exchange a curious glance, but don't say anything. After a few minutes, they hear Bai's muffled voice coming from the room - it sounds like he's on a video call.

Mei leans in closer to the door, straining to hear what's being said. She can't make out much, but it sounds like Bai is pleading his case to someone. She hears the other person speak up, and recognizes the voice as belonging to one of the leaders of the rebellion.

"I don't understand, Bai," the person says, sounding surprised. "We heard you were arrested. What are you doing on this call?"

Bai clears his throat. "Yes, I was, but I managed to escape. Look, I need your help. Two of our people are in trouble. They're trying to rescue a friend who's been wrongly imprisoned by the Spider Queen's forces."

There's a pause, and Mei can almost feel the tension through the door.

"Wrongly imprisoned? How do you know that?"

"He looks like me, and I caused a distraction that led to his arrest. It's my fault. But please, can you help us find him? We don't have the same resources as the main rebellion."

The other person sighs. "Bai, you know better than this. You can't just go around sabotaging things without clearing it with us first. It puts us all in danger."

"I know, I know," Bai says, sounding apologetic. "But we're talking about someone's life here. Can't you make an exception just this once?"

There's another pause, longer this time. Mei and MK exchange a worried glance.

Finally, the other person speaks again. "Fine. I'll see what I can do. But this can't happen again, Bai. We're counting on you to be smart and not put our entire operation at risk."

"I won't let you down," Bai says earnestly.

Mei and MK hear the call end, and a moment later, Bai emerges from the room, looking relieved.

"Well, that could have gone worse," he says to them, a small smile on his face. "We'll have some help finding your friend. But we need to be careful from here on out."
